explanatory comments/crosstagging: This picture shows the beginnings of the Kalka Simla line in Kalka. (Shashwati Talukdar)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: This instance exemplifes a modification of the picturesque aesthetic into the panoramic. The range of what can be seen is expanded. Here topography gets mixed in with the picturesque. (Shashwati Talukdar)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The panoramic is a more mimetic mode concerned with detail; it places the viewer at a distance, somewhere at or close to the center of the picture. The panoramic view in the colonies, however, betrays the affinity of the colonial landscape paintings with the work of army route surveyors, especially those who served as the early cartographers of India. The bird’s-eye view of the terrain is rendered with a clarity which bears more than a passing relationship to cartography. On the one hand, surveillance requires several points of interest to be represented together with clarity. On the other hand, all these different views have to be stitched together into a unified image. The resulting picture is thus a composite that uses the laws of perspective to create a coherent vision which is ultimately a convincing fiction. Given the context of the so-called Great Game, the necessity of the "commanding" view for military superiority, was perhaps, a necessary fiction. It is a fiction nonetheless, because complete surveillance, however desirable, is never quite achievable. (Shashwati Talukdar)(gs)
